question: How has Nvidia's data center revenue changed over the past year?
ground_truth: Nvidia's data center revenue has grown significantly, driven by AI GPU demand. The segment has shown consistent triple-digit growth rates throughout FY2024-2025.
generated_answer:
Atomic Facts with Citations:
- Q4 2025 data center revenue: $35.6B with +16% QoQ growth and +93% YoY growth [C1]
- Q3 2025 data center revenue: $30.8B with +17% QoQ growth and +112% YoY growth [C2]  
- Q2 2025 data center revenue: $26.3B with +16% QoQ growth and +154% YoY growth [C3]
- Q4 2024 data center revenue: $18.4B, up 27% QoQ and up 409% YoY [C5]
- Q3 2024 data center revenue: $14.5B, up 41% sequentially and up 279% YoY [C6]
- Full-year 2024 data center revenue: $47.5B, up 217% [C5]
 Final Answer:
Data center revenue: $35.6B (YoY +93% / QoQ +16%) [C1]
NVIDIA's data center revenue has shown explosive growth over the past year. Starting from $18.4B in Q4 2024 [C5], revenue nearly doubled to $35.6B in Q4 2025 [C1]. The segment maintained strong sequential momentum with consistent double-digit quarterly growth: +27% in Q4 2024 [C5], followed by +16% in Q2 2025 [C3], +17% in Q3 2025 [C2], and +16% in Q4 2025 [C1].
Year-over-year comparisons show accelerating growth rates: 409% in Q4 2024 [C5], 154% in Q2 2025 [C3], 112% in Q3 2025 [C2], and 93% in Q4 2025 [C1]. While YoY growth rates have moderated from peak levels due to higher comparison bases, the absolute revenue increases remain substantial. Full-year 2024 data center revenue reached $47.5B, representing 217% growth [C5].

relevance.reasoning: The answer directly and comprehensively addresses the question about Nvidia's data center revenue changes over the past year. It provides specific quarterly revenue figures (Q4 2024 through Q4 2025), both year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter growth percentages, and full-year totals. The answer shows the trajectory from $18.4B to $35.6B with detailed growth metrics, giving a complete picture of how the revenue has changed over the specified time period.

faithfulness.reasoning: The answer contains mostly accurate information from the context but has some issues. The data center revenue figures are correctly cited: $35.6B for Q4 2025 with +16% QoQ and +93% YoY [C1], $30.8B (actually 30,771) for Q3 2025 [C3], $26.3B (actually 26,272) for Q2 2025 [C4], and $18.4B for Q4 2024 [C8]. However, the answer incorrectly attributes Q3 2024 data center revenue of $14.5B to [C6], when this information actually comes from [C5]. The context in [C5] mentions '$14.5 billion, up 41% sequentially and up 279% year-on-year' for data center revenue. Additionally, the answer references fiscal quarters (Q4 2025, Q3 2025, etc.) but the context doesn't explicitly label these quarters - the answer infers the quarter labels. The full-year 2024 data center revenue of $47.5B and 217% growth is correctly cited from [C8]. Some minor rounding differences exist (30,771 vs 30.8B, 26,272 vs 26.3B). Overall, the core financial data is faithful to the context with minor citation errors and reasonable rounding.

accuracy.reasoning: The generated answer strongly supports the ground truth's claim that Nvidia's data center revenue has grown significantly driven by AI GPU demand. The answer provides extensive specific data showing substantial growth. However, there's a slight discrepancy: the ground truth states 'consistent triple-digit growth rates throughout FY2024-2025,' but the generated answer shows that Q4 2025 YoY growth was 93% (double-digit, not triple-digit). The answer shows triple-digit YoY growth in earlier quarters (409%, 279%, 154%, 112%) but the most recent quarter dropped to 93%. This is a minor factual inconsistency with the 'throughout' claim in the ground truth. The generated answer is much more detailed and provides specific numbers, which is valuable, but it reveals that growth rates have moderated below triple digits in the latest quarter.

metadata.text: 34% sequentially and up more than 200% year-on-year and well above our outlook of $16 billion. Starting with data center. The continued ramp of the NVIDIA HGX platform based on our Hopper Tensor Core GPU architecture, along with InfiniBand end-to-end networking, drove record revenue of $14.5 billion, up 41% sequentially and up 279% year-on-year. NVIDIA HGX with InfiniBand together are essentially the reference architecture for AI supercomputers and data center infrastructures. Some of the most exciting generative AI applications are built and run on NVIDIA, including Adobe, Firefly, ChatGPT, Microsoft 365 Copilot, CoAssist, Now Assist with ServiceNow and Zoom AI Companion. Our data center compute revenue quadrupled from last year and networking revenue nearly tripled.

full-stack computing company with data-center-scale offerings that are reshaping industry. More information at https://nvidianews.nvidia.com/. For further information, contact:

Simona Jankowski	 	Robert Sherbin
Investor Relations	 	Corporate Communications
NVIDIA Corporation	 	NVIDIA Corporation
sjankowski@nvidia.com	 	rsherbin@nvidia.com
Certain statements in this press release including, but not limited to, statements as to: the computer industry going through two simultaneous transitions – accelerated computing and generative AI; installed global data center infrastructure transitioning from general purpose to accelerated computing as companies race to apply generative AI into every product, service and business process; NVIDIA’s entire data center family of products being in production; NVIDIA significantly increasing supply to meet surging demand; NVIDIA’s next quarterly cash dividend; NVIDIA’s financial outlook and expected tax rates for the second quarter of fiscal 2024; the benefits, impact, performance, features and availability of our products and technologies, including NVIDIA Ada, NVIDIA Hopper, NVIDIA Grace Hopper CPU, NVIDIA L4 Tensor Core GPU, NVIDIA AI Foundations, NVIDIA cuLitho software library, NVIDIA H100 Tensor Core GPU, NVIDIA AI Enterprise, GeForce RTX GPUs, DLSS 3, GeForce NOW, NVIDIA Omniverse Cloud, Omniverse, NVIDIA RTX GPUs, and NVIDIA DRIVE Orin; and the benefits and impact of our collaborations, including with Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, ServiceNow, Medtronic, Dell Technologies, CD PROJEKT RED, Microsoft, and BYD are forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause results to be materially different than expectations.

other income and expense are expected to be an income of approximately $250 million, excluding gains and losses from non-affiliated investments. GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates are expected to be 17.0%, plus or minus 1%, excluding any discrete items. Highlights

NVIDIA achieved progress since its previous earnings announcement in these areas: 

Data Center

Fourth-quarter revenue was a record $18.4 billion, up 27% from the previous quarter and up 409% from a year ago. Full-year revenue rose 217% to a record $47.5 billion. Launched, in collaboration with Google, optimizations across NVIDIA’s data center and PC AI platforms for Gemma, Google’s groundbreaking open language models. Expanded its strategic collaboration with Amazon Web Services to host NVIDIA® DGX™ Cloud on AWS.

[Chunk 5] (Score: 8.390)
34% sequentially and up more than 200% year-on-year and well above our outlook of $16 billion. Starting with data center. The continued ramp of the NVIDIA HGX platform based on our Hopper Tensor Core GPU architecture, along with InfiniBand end-to-end networking, drove record revenue of $14.5 billion, up 41% sequentially and up 279% year-on-year. NVIDIA HGX with InfiniBand together are essentially the reference architecture for AI supercomputers and data center infrastructures. Some of the most exciting generative AI applications are built and run on NVIDIA, including Adobe, Firefly, ChatGPT, Microsoft 365 Copilot, CoAssist, Now Assist with ServiceNow and Zoom AI Companion. Our data center compute revenue quadrupled from last year and networking revenue nearly tripled.

NVIDIA achieved progress since its previous earnings announcement in these areas:
